text:
Situation A. Consider These Students' Questions

After trying many examples and looking for patterns, some students had questions about their strategies for adding. For each question, decide if your strategy will work with the condition. Give reasons for your answers.

  • Diego’s Question: Will it work for fractions and decimals?
  • Nicole's Question: What if we changed the order of the two numbers we are adding?
  • Jamar's Question: What if we have more than two integers?

• Diego's Question: Yes, because it is based on absolute values. You can still compare the absolute values of whole numbers, fractions, and decimals. As an example, students might consider having 1/2 red chip and 1/2 black chip. The numerical relationships will not change. Note: students might also include new cases of combinations that they did not consider in the Initial Challenge.
  • Nicole's Question: Changing the order will not change the sum. A chip board can be rotated around to show the numbers in the sum a different order. This will not change the value on the board.
  • Jamar's Question: The addition works the same if you consider the sum of all the positive integers as one number, and then consider the sum of all the negative integers as the other number. Then you can still make judgements based on comparing the absolute values of two numbers.

Situation B. Otis's and Amelia’s Strategy

For each student’s strategy, examine their thinking, and then answer the questions.

Otis’s Strategy using a Chip Board

I used a chip board to represent the expression, +5 +–7. I put five black chips on the board. But I did not know what to do with the –7.

  • How would you help Otis finish his work?
  • How would you represent his work on a number line?

You could add 7 red chips on the board. If we combine the “zeros” we would have –2 left.

(5 + –5) + –2

0 + –2

-2

tiles.title: Otis's Strategy as a Number Line

text:
Amelia’s Strategy Using a Number Line

I wrote the following number line to represent my solution to an addition problem.

  • What addition problem was she trying to solve? Write an equation that represents her work.
  • Describe how you would represent this on a chip board.

From the NUMBER LINE

80 + –55 = 25 (or 80 – 55 = 25)

CHIP BOARD

On the chip board, you would need 80 black chips. Then you add 55 red chips to get 25.

80 + –55 =

(25 + 55) + –55 =

25 + (55 + –55) =

25 + 0 = 25

Situation C. Starting with an Equation

Mr. Bernoski’s students check if their strategies for adding integers work with fractions and decimals. They start with the following:

Using Fractions: Start with -5 + -3 = -8. Evaluate the following:
Using Decimals: Start with -8 + (+5) = -3. Evaluate the following:

1. Before doing the calculation, predict whether the sum will be positive, negative, or zero.

2. Use the information represented by each equation to evaluate the following related calculations.

1. Predictions will vary.
